page.title: 13PORTHOLME
page.content: Portholme meadow covers 247 acres and is probably the largest of its kind in the country.The name means 'an island where the river meets the road.' Today the meadow is noted for its{wild {flowers,}some of which are{quite rare. To be given its proper title Portholme is an{enclosed common.}This in itself is a contradiction.It is one of only two in the country to be defined thus. Originally the meadow was owned by the Lord of the Manor. Now it is owned by the parishes of Brampton,Huntingdon and Godmanchester. The villagers of these places have the right to graze animals on the eddage. Some of the farmers in the area also have the right to cut the hay on the meadow.Although it is common land people must stick to the footpaths, of which there are three, connecting the parishes concerned.
